votes have been cast the people have
spoken
but how do we go from here to here well
it all starts through a magic number 326
that's half the seats in house of
commons plus one and it's the number all
parties dream of because it means they
have an overall majority in parliament
quick sidebar in practice it's a little
bit less than that because some MPs
never vote the speaker yet that's the
guy and his deputies don't and over in

away because they don't recognize the

pretty straightforward
it means they get to form a majority
government the leader of that party can
jump in a car go straight to [ __ ]
Palace and ask the Queen for permission
to form a government though an outgoing
Prime Minister if it's a different
person actually has to make the same

absolute majority of MPs in the Commons
usually means the governing party has
enough support to pass laws and get
things done
that's why parties have whips basically
people who try to convince MPs to vote
in line with their own party even the
whips weren't able to stop loads of MPs
rebelling over brexit so the bigger a
party's majority the more Headroom they
have to deal with those rebellious MPs
but what if no party reaches the magic
number of 326 on election day that's
when we get what is called a hung
parliament admittedly this used to be
quite rare but it has happened in two of
the last three elections so really all
bets are off a hung parliament is a real
headache mainly because it means parties
might actually have to cooperate to get
into or hold on to power so here are two
options on how a government is formed in
the event of a hung Parliament's option
one two parties or more with a combined
majority of 326 MPs or more get together
to form a coalition government they will
decide
find closed doors will be given the most
important roles and what policies they
might compromise on that's what happened
in 2010 and just look at how happy
everyone seemed to be back then froze
you have a combined majority to actually
govern with Kahn's parties have to
compromise and my alienate some of their
supporters option to the party with the
most seats tries to form our minority
governments so they don't have a
majority in the Commons but they govern
anyway in order to pass laws the
government asks for occasional support
from another party that party might
agree to back the government on the most
important votes and in exchange the
government guarantees them influence
over things they care about in 2017 then
Prime Minister trees made didn't form a
coalition I had an arrangement with the
DUP in Northern Ireland that meant she
could mostly count on their votes this
is called a confidence and supply
agreements the pros there's a government
the cons it can be difficult for that
government to actually get things done
confused yet no then I'll add a little
bit more complexity keep in mind that
the UK has no written constitution so
much of how the government is formed is
based on convention and there can be
exceptions to how things are done in the
1923 election this guy formed the first
Labour government with the support from
another party even though the
Conservatives had won the most seats
overall so what can we take away from
this the party of the most MPs in
Parliament usually gets to form the
government but the closer the election
results the more complicated things can
